Political Agent, Bahrain. No T/344 Dated 20th and Received 22nd .^ugust, 1945. United States Army Survey Mission under Lieutenant Moore of United States Army has been working on .ruein' 1 ■'’oast since June taking ground ?fixtures for KErifaKtiEK verification of maps already made by aerial photograph. 2 . Moore wishes to proceed to Muscat early in September to contact Sultan and you in order to continue survey in Muscat. He wishes to travel along ?coastline and line parallel to it 50 sddbgs balf 100 miles inland. Please inform Sultan. I - GALLO 1 . .AI -l 0 I' <$> Telegram S(Pad) 3 From Political Resident at Shiraz, To Political ikgent, Muscat. India iffice, London. No T/345 Dated 20th and Received 22nd August, 1945. My immediately preceding telegram. .OP SRCBRT GU^i D ^American .survey party is v/orking in conjunction with our survey branch i iddle Last, who support inclusion of Muscat within area of survey provided there is no political ?objection . 2. he cannot appear non co-operative and I see no objection to travel along coast. 3. In view hoy/ever of delicate situation in hinterland and Sultan’s consequent reluctance + c ^rwit penetration in this area by British Oil and Locust parties, I presume he can be counted on to refuse permission for xkp±k survey party to travel along proposed line' 50 miles inland ? From transport aspect also this route seems hardly practicable. 4. District ion-as in r.y immediately preceding telegram (addressed Political a.gent, Muscat, India Office, London) -, GALLO*. .aY -Ho.S.1149-6/34. iy dear friend His Britannic Majesty's Consulate, Muscat, Dated 23rd. August, 1945. I have been instructed by the Hon'ble the Political Resident to inform Your Highness that an United States Anqy Survey Mission under the command of Lt. Moore of the United States Amy wishes to visit Muscat early in September. This Mission has been working on the Trucial Coast since June taking ground fixtures for the verification of maps made by aerial * photography. Lt. Moore wishes to visit Your highness in Sep tember in order to carry out survey work in Muscat territory and to arrange for hi a party to travel on a line parellol to the coast and 50 miles inland for this purpose. 2. It is not clear from the information so far received whether it is the intention that only the Patinah coast should be surveyed or whether it is desired to survey the whole of the coast line of Muscat territory; but it seems probable that the Survey Mission will wish to undertake latter project. Apart from the transport difficulties which will arise from attempting to travel on a line 50 miles inland from the coast, the proposed operations of the survey party will presumably be impracticable for the same reasons which led to Your Highness to advise against the visit of a locust party to the hinterland this winter. In these circumstances it might fce as well to reply that provided the survey party keep within the coastal areas under Your Ilighnesd control there would be no objection to their activities, but that in the present circumstances it is not possible for them to operate in Oman. This is of-courae subject to Your Highness seeing no objection to a survey of your territories being car ried out. 3. I shall be grateful if Your Highness will kindly le t me know as early as possible the reply you wish me to send to the Hon'ble the Political Resident. f)e N His Highness Saiyid Said tin Taimur,- ~ r oiir. Highnesaj 1 sincere friend,f'* I. S. 1149-6/34 dated the 4Sl O/XAUs'd f Please refer to your letter No 23rd. August 1945. I shall send you my reply on the subject after I have had an opportunity of discussing it with you. Meanwhile the matter is under my consideration. S' OUlJL ^ 7^-^ Mr. R. I. Hallows His Britannic Majesty’s Consul Muscat. iI S/55 Muscat 27th, Augustl945 V / In reply to your letter No. S.1149-6/54 of the 23rd. August 1945 we wish to inform you that, while we have no objec- .. tion to Lt. Moore visiting us in Muscat and permit him to under take survey work in the coastal areas as we shall explain to him, we feel it necessary to point out that such facilities must now be treated on a peace time basis for which negotiations may be conducted in the usual manner. We shall expect to receive an approach from our friend the U. S. A. Government. We wish to make it clear in conclusion that it will be impossible for the party to travel at a distance of 50 miles from the coast at present. Mr. R. I. Hallows His Britannic Majesty’s Consul Muscat.3±§gram ?om To No S.II63 Dated the 2 th August, 1945. Political Agent,. liiscat. Political Res:’dent at Shiraz. 4^0f O' Your t le Tara Ho of 20th August. Sultan has replied that (a) it is impossible repeat impossible for Survey Party to travel 50 miles from coastline at present time. (b) he has no objection-to hoore visiting hi at huscat. (c) he permits survey work in coi stal areas whose' limits he will describe to moofe.at htuscat. (d)' Such facilities should now be consider jg on peace-time basis and he will therefore expect to receive an approach from United States Government in due course if matter is pursued. - POLITICAL -JK? if- It' 6/34 Telegranio Q.T*C From,, Political Resident, Bushire To. Political Agent, Muscat No. 1532 Dated the 9th received the 10th October, 1945 Your telegram No.S 1163 August 28th.- Please inform Sultan that American ? Survey Party propose leaving Bahrain for Muscat on October 14th. Galloway ft a■'I » 1 6/34 Telegram. GTC From. ' Political Agent, Muscat To. Political Agent, Bahrain No. S 1343 Dated the 10th October, 1945 Political Resident informs me that American Survey Party propose leaving Bahrain for Muscat on October 14th. Please telegraph (a) size of party (b) number £f officers (c) Approximated dated of arrival Muscat and (d) how they are travelling. Political.Telegram. GTC From. Britagent, Sharjah To. Political Agent, Muscat No.1067 Dated Ahd received the 17th October, 1945 Important . . \ (£>' 1 \ American Survey Party consisting of 3 G.I's, 1 officer ( Lieutenant Moore ) 1 interpreter, 1 guide and two local drivers propose leaving Sharjah for Muscat on October 20th with six cars. They will travel via WADI AL QAAR along Batinah. Approximate date of arrival Muscat October 26th. Britagent. ■■mTelegram. GTC From. Political Agent, Muscat To. Britagent, Sharjah No.3 1383 Dated the 17th October, 1945 Important. equipment with them )1) Yout telegram No. 1067 of 17th October. Please confirm that party will bring tents and camp * Political.■ 1 } Political Apency, ’Muscat. i>ai od the 19th December, 194^ Dear Colonel Hay, 1 enclose for your information a copy of a lot^er addressed by the American Consul at Dhahran tc the Sultan, together with a copy of its enclosure. (/2U fJo.C 834-8/62 The Sultan seemed upset to discover that Thome hoi allowed himself to act as a medium for correspondence between on of the Sheikhs of the interior and a foreign Consul, but contented him self by saying he proposed to warn Thoms not to repeat such an indiscretion. Yours sincerely. The Hon'ble Lt-Col T .R.iiay, C.S.I., C.I. Political Resident, Persian Gulf, Pahrain. ;V 700/WEB/ah The Foreign Service of the United States of America. Department of State. AMERICAN CONSULATE Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, November 15, 1946< His Highness Said bin Taimur, Sultan of Muscat and Oman, Muscat. Your Highness I have the honour to transmit herewith Consul Parker T. Hart’s letter of November 13 to Sheikh Sulaiman bin Humayer A1 Nabhani, which Your Highness is700/PTH/db The Foreign Service of the United States of America. Department of State. AMERICAN CONSULATE Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, November 13, 1946 From Parker T. Hart, American Consul To Sheikh Sulaiman bin Humayer A1 Nabhani, Tenoof, Jebel Akhdhar, Oman. Greetings and best wishes. I was most happy to receive your friendly letter of July 24, 1946, transmitted by the hand of our good friend Dr.W.Welles Thoms, and I reciprocate heartily your cordial greetings and those of your sons Sultan and Humayer. As I am now departing from Dhahran for the United States I am delivering my reply to my successor Consul Waldo E.Bailey, who will forward it to you through His Highness Said bin Taimur, Sultan of Muscat and Oman. It is a pleasure and an honour to have news of you through Dr.Thoms and to learn that you have ex tended to him such gracious hospitality and assistance. For this, Consul Bailey joins me in expressing deepest thanks. May the friendly relations between Arabs and Americans continue to be a factor for stability and peace. God keep you and your family welland happy, and give you long life. Sd. Parker T. Hartv,. £) British Middle East Office, Cairo 5th February, 1947 SECRET Dear Hay, This is in reply to your D.0.NO.95-S of the 15th January about Mr. Sullivan. He is on the diplomatic list here and is described as 'Attache Adjoint (Questions Petrolieres)', his appointment dating from April, 1946. I gather that in normal life he was an accounts clerk, or something of the kind, in one of the American oil companies and after the war was appointed as assistant to the then American Oil Attache, a senior man by the name of Pagett. Pagett has since faded out but Sullivan has stayed on. The general impression 1 gather is that he is carving out a job for himself by asking a lot of questions from anybody he can get hold of, compiling statistics and, to be frank, making a general nuisance of himslagf. It would be unwise to trust him too far but, on the other hand, there is no reason to suppose that he is visions or harmful. He is a hail-fellow- well-met type of man who goes in a good deal for social functions. On the whole, I should say tnat he should be treated with a certain amount of reserve but handled tactfully. Yours sincerely, (Signed) A. Overton Colonel W.R. Hay, Political Resident, Persian Gulf. ' PERSIAN GULF RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN, the 15th January, 1947 SECny; P,tPtN&t£5=£ My dear Sir Arnold, On the 11th January I received a call from Childs, the American Minister at Jeddah. He brought with him one Don. J. Sullivan who described hirasfcef as the American Oil Attache for the Middle East, and asked me a number of pertinent questions about oil matters In the Gulf. He stated his intention of returning here shortly when he hopes to Interview Packer, the local Petroleum Concessions Limited Manager, and also to visit the Trucial Coast and find out what Petroleum Concessions Limited are doing there. 2. I should be grateful for anything you can let me know about Sullivan. I gather he made himself rather unpopular with the American Manager of the BAPCO here and I think we may find him a bit of a nuisance. As however he was introduced to me by Childs I propose to give such assistance in the way of travel facilities as is possible and any information about oil developments which is not of a highly confidential nature. Yours sincerely, (Signed) W. F. Hay. Sir Arnold Overton, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., M.C.

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 6/34 Foreign Interests: American Interests in the Persian Gulf'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 21; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-16; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence concerning visits made to the Gulf by American officials. The majority of the correspondence in the file relates to a visit to Muscat made by the US Army Survey Mission in 1945.
